text:
SKELETON

A hinge joint is a common class of synovial joint that includes the ankle, elbow, and knee joints. Hinge joints are formed between two or more bones where the bones can only move along one axis to flex or extend.

The ball and socket joint (or sphenoid joint), is a type of synovial joint in which the ball-shaped surface of one rounded bone fits into the cup-like depression of another bone. The distal bone is capable of motion around an indefinite number of axis, which have one

A gliding joint, also known as a plane joint or planar joint, is a common type of synovial joint formed between bones that meet at flat or nearly flat articular surfaces. Gliding joints allow the bones to glide past one another in any direction along the plane of the joint — up and down, left and right, and diagonally.

Suture joints are found in the skull.

Atlas is the first cervical vertebra, which supports the skull whereas axis is the second cervical vertebra, which forms the pivot upon the atlas. Furthermore, atlas help to hold the head upright while axis allows the head to turn side to side. Atlas is the bone the peck on which the skull rests.

Odontophore is a skeletal structure in the mollusks (e.g. snail). It is a structure at the base of the mouth of most mollusks over which the radula is drawn back and forth in breaking up food.

The ilium is the uppermost and largest part of the hip bone, and appears in most vertebrates including mammals and birds, but not bony fish. 

The pubis (also called pubic bone) is a paired bone that forms the anterior part of the hip bone, and the anterior and inferior boundary of the obturator foramen. 

The obturator foramen is the large opening created by the ischium and pubis bones, of the pelvis through which nerves and blood vessels pass. 

The pubic symphysis is a secondary cartilaginous joint located between the left and right pubic bones near the midline of the body. The left and right pubic bones join at the pubic symphysis.

 

UNN PUTME Examples

1. Odontophore is a skeletal structure in the phylum of

A. pisses B. echinoderms C. Mollusca D. amphibians

(Odontophore is a skeletal structure in the mollusks (e.g snail). It is a structure at the base of the mouth of most mollusks over which the radula is drawn back and forth in breaking up food, 2006/2007, no 4)

 

2. The two halves of the pelvic girdle are joined together at the 

A. ilium B. pubis C. obturator foramen D. pubic symphysis

(D. The ilium is the uppermost and largest part of the hip bone, and appears in most vertebrates including mammals and birds, but not bony fish, 2019/2020, no 2)

 

3. Skeletal structures of terrestrial animals are more elaborate than those of aquatic vertebrates because

A. air is more mobile than water B. water contains more nutrients than air C. movement is much easier in air than on water D. density of water is greater than that air

(D. The density of water is greater than that air, 2012/2013 DE, no 14)

 

4. The bone the peck on which the skull rests is called

A. odontoid process B. axis C. atlas D. occipital condyle

(C. atlas help to hold the head upright while axis allows the head to turn side to side. Atlas is the bone the peck on which the skull rests, 2012/2013, no 7)

 

JAMB Examples

1. The chitin in the exoskeleton of many arthropods is strengthened by

A. lids B. proteins C. calcium compounds D. organic salt

(C. calcium compounds)

 

2. Suture joint is found in the 

A. hip B. ankle C. skull D. elbow

(C. skull)

 

3. The vertebrae that allows the skull to nod and rotate are

A. axis and cervical B. atlas and thoracis C. axis and atlas D. atlas and cervical

(C. axis and atlas)
